titleStmt.title: A Conversation at the Market
TUNOCENT Dataset
titleStmt.funder: Funded by the FWF Austrian Science Fund under the number P 31647

publicationStmt.distributor: Austrian Center for Digital Humanities and Cultural Heritage

media.desc: The informant has not explicitly agreed to the publication of the audio recording. Thus, the audio recording is available only to the research project itself.

monogr.title: The Arabic Dialect of Testour (Northwestern Tunisia): A phonological and morphological analysis

biblStruct.note: The town of Testour lies close to the Medjerda river in northwestern Tunisia and it was founded in the 17th century by the Muslim Moriscan community who was exiled from Spain, after the Reconquista led to a rise in Christian zeal in the Iberian peninsula. By making North Africa their new home, the Moriscos introduced their customs, agriculture, architecture, food and dress amongst many other things, to these new towns and to the locals. The inhabitants of Testour today claim that they are the descendants of the Moriscos, and as such as keen to practice typical Moriscan trades, such as producing the chéchia hat and celebrating the Maʔlūf music. This master’s thesis aims at documenting some of the phonological and morphological features of the Arabic dialect of the present community of Testour, on which to my knowledge, no such linguistic works currently exists. The recordings on which this thesis is based have been collected during the framework of the TUNOCENT project hosted by the University of Vienna, which strives to collect and document the dialects of certain towns in northwestern and central Tunisia. The outcome of this thesis is to put Testour on the linguistic map of Tunisia, a country on which relatively very little has been done in this regard, as well as to hopefully contribute a better insight on the ambiguous dialectal classifications in Tunisia.

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the TUNOCENT teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the arche prefix are pointers to resources archived in the long-term repository ARCHE.
Private URIs using the assets prefix are pointers to assets used by the TUNOCENT web application.
Private URIs using the datatypes.vicav.fl prefix are pointers to feature lists.
Private URIs using the datatypes.vicav.st prefix are pointers to VICAV sample texts.
Private URIs using the datatypes.tunocent.ums prefix are pointers to transcribed texts of unmonitored speech.
Private URIs using the datatypes.tunocent.pp prefix are pointers to TUNOCENT place profiles.

spanGrp.span: What does she want?
Speak about the market. She (...), the dialect, give her information about the language.
About the dialect?
The language, yes.
This is the wholesale market. We sell the merchandise; Should I always speak in Arabic to you?
She understands Arabic.
With the Testouri dialect.
With the Testouri dialect, the Testouri dialect, do you understand me? Here, the farmer, this is a big shop. The government sets it up now, it is called the wholesale market.
The farmer grows his produce and brings it here to the market. We sell it to the greengrocer who sells it in small quantities, do you understand me?
And we take our share and we pass on the money which belongs to the farmer.
And Testour is an Andalusian town. Do you want me to tell you a bit about Testour? It is an Andalusian town.
Most of the Andalusians came from 1610, something like that. They came to Testour. Do you understand me?
They are called the Moriscos, they are Andalusians. They came as migrants, migrants, they came here as migrants. They settled in Soliman.
They lived in Soliman, a town called Soliman in Tunisia, and they lived here in Testour, do you understand me?
And they brought with them their customs and traditions, which were many fruits, now many fruits are from Spain
Such as pomegranates, apricots, do you understand me? We have, for example, saffron.
Saffron
And with regards to the flowers, they brought the jasmine, they brought the Arabian jasmine from there, do you understand me?
And they brought varieties of food, do you understand me? A lot of them.
What else would you like me to tell you about Testour?
It is a charming town
An agricultural town, it is an agricultural town, it doesn’t have an industrial area.
The people here live off, most people here live off agriculture, do you understand me?
Right, it is an unimportant and average town, a fine and average town, do you understand?
And the feasts, what do you celebrate?
We celebrate the feasts, our religious feasts mostly. The religious feasts.
We have Eid al-Fitr (the small Eid) and the Eid al-Adha (the big Eid).
Eid al-Fitr is the one in which traditional pastry is baked; there is the ġṛayyba, there is the makrouth, do you understand me?
And there is the pastry rings. Every person bakes what he likes, do you understand me? The big feast is Eid al-Adha, it is well known for the lamb, do you understand? Eid al-Adha.
What is it that we have? We have the month of Ramadan, all the Muslims celebrate it, do you understand me?
Do you understand me?
No, no, ça va. We all celebrate it, as you know. You know abour Ramadan, right? Do you fast or not?
You don’t fast. God willing you will start fasting, God willing, do you understand me?
Do you know when the period of fasting is? From sunrise until sunset, do you understand?
These are some of our official feasts. There is also the feast where we celebrate the birth of the prophet Mohammad.
Bon, in Testour, we also celebrate it greatly by making the ʕaṣīda
There are different varieties of the ʕaṣīda, the majority would make it with pine nuts.
Do you know what pine nuts are?
The majority would make the ʕaṣīda with pine nuts.
And those who cannot afford it, they would make the white ʕaṣīda, do you understand me? Out of flour, do you understand me? That’s it.
Welcome to Testour, welcome, pleased to meet you, do you understand me?
What would you like me to tell you more about?
No, it is enough...
